occurrences.line_text: That he besought him downe by him to sit,
So downe he sate, and with delightfull pleasure
And stouping downe to her in drery swound,
Downe in a dale forby a riuers syde,
So downe he tooke his Lady in distresse,
That wanting breath, him downe to ground he cast;
So vp and downe he wandred many a mile,
That made him downe vnto the earth encline;
As to his Lord, and downe his weapons layd,
And falleth downe to ground like senselesse thing,
And throwing downe his load out of his hand,
Gan stoupe, and falling downe with humble awe,
That downe he kept him with his scornefull sway,
They downe him hold, and fast with cords do bynde,
But wayt aduantage, when they downe did light.
And is behinde me trodden downe of Scorne,
Downe on his golden feete he often gazed,
Whom with his weight vnweldy downe he held,
And downe him plucking, with his nayles and teeth
So sore him scourgeth, that the bloud downe followeth.
And sitting downe, her selfe a while bethought
Were downe to them descended in that earthly vew.
And through ambition downe themselues doe driue
And when I wearie am, I downe doe lay
His siluer waues did softly tumble downe,
At last as there he romed vp and downe,
Tho sitting downe by them vpon the greene,
And robd the Chancell, and the deskes downe threw,
And being downe, ere he new helpe could call,
His shield he on him threw, and fast downe held;
Is forcibly kept downe, till he be throughly queld.
To be downe held, and maystred so with might,
Whilest Calidore him vnder him downe threw;
So off he did his shield, and downeward layd
Till euening, that the Sunne gan downward bend.
Ne could it vpward come, nor downward passe,
And on his tender lips the downy heare
But without dowre the wise Cordelia
To whom but little dowre allotted was;
Her vertue was the dowre, that did delight.
What better dowre can to a dame be hight?
Withouten dowre or composition;
And th'hearts of men, as your eternall dowre,
And nature me endu'd with plenteous dowre,
And with Sans-foyes dead dowry you endew.
Together with her selfe in dowry free;
Being the dowry of his wife well knowne,
She weakely started, yet she nothing drad:
Drad for his derring do, and bloudy deed;
That Ladies safetie is sore to be drad:
As if no sorrow she ne felt ne drad;
Iealous suspect as true vntruely drad,
But now his cruelty so sore she drad,
Wayting what end would be of that same daunger drad.
And keepe your body from the daunger drad:
Deuizing of his loue more, then of daunger drad.
And by his false allurements wylie draft
So drag'd him through the waues in scornefull state,
Vpon his foe, a Dragon horrible and stearne.
Now like a foxe, now like a dragon fell,
A dreadfull Dragon with an hideous trayne,
A Dragon fiers encountreth in his flight,
For all the crest a Dragon did enfold
An huge great Dragon horrible in sight,
With that fire-mouthed Dragon, horrible and bright?
The knight with that old Dragon fights
Eftsoones that dreadfull Dragon they espide,
Whylome, before that cursed Dragon got
Till that dread Dragon all did ouerthrow.
But when they came, where that dead Dragon lay,
A wounded Dragon vnder him did ly,
A monstrous Dragon, full of fearefull vglinesse.
Of many Dragonets, his fruitfull seed;
To tell, how he had seene the Dragons fatall fall.
Dragons, and Minotaures, and feendes of hell,
A Dragons taile, whose sting without redresse
A dram of sweet is worth a pound of sowre:
For euery dram of hony therein found,
That not a dram was missing of their right,
That I mote drinke the cup, whereof she dranke:
And ready dight with drapets festiuall,
Shrieking his balefull note, which euer draue
The which for promise of great meed, vs draue
Both in his armes, and crowne, and by that draught
And in her lap did shed her idle draught,
Whereof full glad for thirst, ech drunk an harty draught.
She sent an arrow forth with mighty draught,
And fifty sisters water in leake vessels draw.
And them constraine in equall teme to draw.
Vnto his aide she hastily did draw
To draw thy dayes forth to their last degree?
And all that might him to perdition draw;
And to an hill her selfe with draw aside,
Thrise he assayd it from his foot to draw,
And thrise in vaine to draw it did assay,
And back retyrd, his life bloud forth with all did draw.
And draw them from pursuit of praise and fame,
Would from the right way seeke to draw him wide,
The little barke vnto the shore to draw,
Which with great vprore preaced to draw nere
Bidding them nigher draw vnto the shore;
To draw their boate within the vtmost bound
And draw from on this iourney to proceede.
And counseld well, him forward thence did draw.
For then some hope I might vnto me draw,
All things decay in time, and to their end do draw.
Which foure great Hippodames did draw in temewise tyde.
That no man forth might draw, ne no man remedye.
To draw them longer out, and better twine,
To draw their dayes vnto the vtmost date,
Ne thinke th'affection of her hart to draw
Vnto that purposd place I did me draw,
To come where thou doest draw them with desire:
In hope thereby her to his bent to draw:
Who as they to the passage gan to draw,
And all the wealth of rich men to the poore will draw.
Through woods, and rocks, and mountaines they did draw
She could it sternely draw, that all the world dismayde.
Towards the westerne brim begins to draw,
She towards him in hast her selfe did draw,
To whom himselfe he hastily did draw,
Yet knowing that her Knight now neare did draw,
Vnto his Inne began to draw apace;
To draw him from his deare beloued dame,
See how they doe the Lady hale and draw.
Their happie flockes, nor daunger to them draw:
Nor draw vnto the lure of his lewd lay,
Yet durst he not draw backe; nor once withstand
On which was drawen faire, in colours fit,
The rest of other fishes drawen weare,
And from her partie eftsoones was drawen cleene.
He hath his shield redeem'd, and foorth his sword he drawes.
Or what within his reach he euer drawes.
On who so commeth nigh; yet nigh it drawes
Now (sayd the Lady) draweth toward night,
They drawing nigh, vnto their God present
And drawing nigh him said, Ah misborne Elfe,
To tell that dawning day is drawing neare,
Drawing to him the eyes of all around,
Which drawing backe, he looked euermore
And drawing both their swords with rage extreme,
And with vnwearied fingers drawing out
Which drawing softly forth out of the darke,
And drawing nigh, when as he plaine descride
But drawing nigh, ere he her well beheld;
And drawing him out of the open hall,
And drawing backe deceiued their intent;
Yet when she reckned them, still drawing neare,
He drawing neare, began to greete them faire,
Had it forslackt. But now time drawing ny,
And drawing thence his speach another way,
And fiercely drawing forth his blade, doth sweare,
Drawne of faire Pecocks, that excell in pride,
But this was drawne of six vnequall beasts,
For they haue oft drawne many a wandring wight
Was drawne vpon the waues, that fomed him around.
Was drawne forth, and in siluer basin layd,
And drawne it was (that wonder is to tell)
Drawne with the powre of an heart-robbing eye,
And drawne of cruell steedes, which he had fed
Or drawne forth from her by diuine extreate.
That haue her drawne to all this troublous strife,
Drawne with that Ladies loud and piteous shright,
Would not for ought be drawne to former drede,
Yet nothing did he dread, but euer was ydrad.
For present cause was none of dread her to dismay.
The Fort, that Ladies hold in soueraigne dread.
And that dread Lyons looke her cast in deadly hew.
Whose needlesse dread for to remoue away,
Whom seeing such, for dread he durst not show
With dread whereof his chasing steedes aghast,
The mother of dread darknesse, and let stay
She more amaz'd, in double dread doth dwell;
And oft for dread of hurt would him aduise,
He set the false Duessa, for more aw and dread.
Mine onely foe, mine onely deadly dread,
And all his senses were with suddeine dread dismayd.
Vpstaring stiffe, dismayd with vncouth dread;
That bare-head knight for dread and dolefull teene,
From tyrans rage, and euer-dying dread,
As was her sister; whether dread did dwell,
Ne ought the powre of mighty men did dread
For dread of that huge feend emprisond be
And downe he fell, with dread of shame sore terrifide.
Till that dread Dragon all did ouerthrow.
Durst not approch for dread, which she misdeem'd,
Vile Caytiue, vassall of dread and despaire,
For dread of soaring hauke her selfe hath hid,
That thee against me drew with so impetuous dread.
And her sweet selfe without dread, or disdaine,
(So Loue the dread of daunger doth despise)
First got with guile, and then preseru'd with dread,
And was with dread and horrour compassed around.
But dread of death and dolour doe away;
Still waites for death with dread and trembling aw;
For dread of whom, and for those Picts annoyes,
But fiercely forward came withouten dread,
Dare not for dread his hardy hand expose,
Ah my deare daughter, ah my dearest dread,
And win thy will: Therefore away doe dread;
But thy dread darts in none doe triumph more,
For dread of daunger, which it might portend:
Of his coosin Constantius without dread
Whose brother Oswin, daunted with like dread,
The Gods doe dread, he dearely shall abye:
But shewd by outward signes, that dread her sence did daze.
That it she shund no lesse, then dread to die,
From dread of her reuenging fathers hond:
She you from death, you me from dread redeemed.
Thy labour all is lost, I greatly dread,
Iust cause of dread, that makes ye doubt so sore?
But yet durst not for dread approchen nie,
Matter of doubt and dread suspitious,
To ioylesse dread, and mak'st the louing hart
But alwayes did their dread encounter fly:
Then enterprised prayse for dread to disauaunce.
Consuming Riotise, and guilty Dread
Yet dread of shame, and doubt of fowle dishonor
For dread of blame and honours blemishment;
That dread thereof, and his redoubted might
From daungers dread to ward his naked side,
To let them passe at will, for dread of shame.
And ghesse the man to be dismayd with gealous dread.
Hath doen to noble knights, that many makes him dread.
With needelesse dread, till certaintie ye heare:
Belphebe saues from dread:
Her selfe downe soust, she waked out of dread
But darknesse and dread horrour, where she dwelt,
Vnhappy mayd (then answerd she) whose dread
For dread of her displeasures vtmost proofe.
Then death it selfe more dread and desperate.
Withouten dread of perill to repaire
But as one daunted with her presence dread,
Fearlesse of fortunes chaunge or enuies dread,
Of whom he gan enquire his cause of dread;
No lesse did Daunger threaten me with dread,
As on the ground, without dismay or dread:
Dread Souerayne Goddesse, that doest highest sit
That furthest Nations filles with awfull dread,
The club of Iustice dread, with kingly powre endewed.
True loue despiseth shame, when life is cald in dread.
His horses backe, for dread of being drownd,
For dread of their deuouring enemie,
To keepe a nightly watch, for dread of treachery.
From the dread daunger of his weapon keene,
But dread of shame my doubtfull lips doth still restraine.
Ah my deare dread (said then the faithfull Mayd)
Can dread of ought your dreadlesse hart withhold,
That many hath with dread of death dismayd,
And lay vpon him, for his greater dread,
And then came Daunger threatning hidden dread,
Fro dangers dread his doubtfull life to saue;
Whom neither dread of God, that deuils bindes,
He will not bide the daunger of such dread,
And as he past afore withouten dread,
That he for dread of death gan loude to crie
Then doe your selfe, for dread of shame, forgoe
Therefore he wild her doe away all dread;
In dread of death, his heasts did gladly heare,
Whose gealous dread induring not a peare,
To my dread Soueraine, when I it assayd,
But forst him gape and gaspe, with dread aghast,
Twixt darkenesse dread, and hope of liuing light,
The saluage nation doth all dread despize:
Kept, and deliuered me from deadly dread.
Whylest euery ioynt for dread of death did quake,
But kept aloofe for dread to be descryde,
So fresh the image of her former dread,
For dread of daunger, not to be redrest,
The mightie ones, affrayd of euery chaunges dread.
That mote empaire my peace with daungers dread.
For dread of them vnwares to be descryde,
Ne durst abide behind, for dread of worse effort.
Which she streight way for dread least, if her syre
Endeuouring my dreadded name to raise
Are dreadded most, and feared for their powre:
And thou most dreaded impe of highest Ioue,
And threatned vnto him the dreaded name
Without regard of armes and dreaded fight:
From dreaded storme of his disdainfull spight:
And doubled strokes, like dreaded thunders threat:
Saying, Yet O thou dreaded Dame, I craue
That dreaded Night in brightest day hath place,
Then for to make her dreaded more of men,
Had wrought that horror strange, and dar'd his dreaded powre.
That now I weene Ioues dreaded thunder light
As chicken newly hatcht, from dreaded destiny.
Of my most dreaded Soueraigne I recount,
And dreaded name shall giue in that sad day:
His dreaded head, and the old sparkes renew
And mighty people, dreaded more then all
Thereto he was a doughtie dreaded knight,
That made them dreaded much of all men farre and nie.
That they were doughtie knights of dreaded name;
His name was Daunger dreaded ouer all,
Which steely brand, to make him dreaded more,
So sitting high in dreaded souerayntie,
And set a Seneschall of dreaded might,
Then pardon me, most dreaded Soueraine,
Of dreaded daunger might his doubtfull humour feed.
Which durst her dreaded reskue enterprize,
In thousand dreadful shapes doth mongst them stalke,
Breedes dreadfull doubts: Oft fire is without smoke,
At last whenas the dreadfull passion
Discoursing of her dreadfull late distresse,
A dreadfull Dragon with an hideous trayne,
But dreadfull Furies, which their chaines haue brast,
Before the threshold dreadfull Cerberus
The dreadfull spectacle of that sad house of Pride.
And sturdie courage tame with dreadfull aw,
For loue of me leaue off this dreadfull play;
Till at the last he heard a dreadfull sownd,
And towardes him with dreadfull fury praunce;
Vpon this dreadfull Beast with seuenfold head
His golden wings: his dreadfull hideous hed
Which haue endured many a dreadfull stowre,
And lifting vp his dreadfull club on hight,
Her dreadfull beast, who swolne with bloud of late
And threatning high his dreadfull stroke did see,
Defiled was, that dreadfull was to vew,
Ne bring him forth in face of dreadfull fight,
Eftsoones that dreadfull Dragon they espide,
Soone as thy dreadfull trompe begins to sownd;
By this the dreadfull Beast drew nigh to hand,
Those glaring lampes were set, that made a dreadfull shade.
With dreadfull poyse is from the mayneland rift,
To weet, what dreadfull thing was there in hand;
And threatned death with dreadfull countenaunce,
And soone his dreadfull blade about he cast,
Fly, O Pyrrochles, fly the dreadfull warre,
That dreadfull feend, which did behind him wayt,
Loe where the dreadfull Death behind thy backe doth stond.
But with his dreadfull hornes them driues afore,
They brought forth Giants and such dreadfull wights,
The Romane legion in dreadfull fight:
With which they dayly made most dreadfull battery.
And fierce of force, was dreadfull to report:
Thus these twelue troupes with dreadfull puissance
Was much dismayed with that dreadfull sight:
They reard a most outrageous dreadfull yelling cry,
And th'one of them with dreadfull yelling cry,
Depending from on high, dreadfull to sight,
Or that darke dreadfull hole of Tartare steepe,
All dreadfull pourtraicts of deformitee:
The dreadfull Fish, that hath deseru'd the name
Of Death, and like him lookes in dreadfull hew,
With dreadfull noise, and hollow rombling rore,
For all that here on earth we dreadfull hold,
And all that dreadfull Armie fast gan flye
The ill-faste Owle, deaths dreadfull messengere,
And bent his dreadfull speare against the others head.
Dreadfull of daunger, that mote him betyde,
But with her dreadfull strokes were all dismayd:
Of dreadfull things the same was put to flight,
To trauell, goe to see that dreadfull place:
First entering, the dreadfull Mage there found
Then shall he issew forth with dreadfull might,
The dreadfull speare and shield to exercize:
And dreadfull visions, in the which aliue
Her dreadfull weapon she to him addrest,
To dreadfull shapes he did himselfe transforme,
That dreadfull sound the boasters hart did thrill,
And many dreadfull feends hath pointed to her gard.
And dreadfull horrour did all entraunce choke,
With dreadfull thunder and lightning atwixt,
Made of Beares skin, that him more dreadfull made,
Yet his owne face was dreadfull, ne did need
With ghastly lookes and dreadfull drerihed;
Full dreadfull things out of that balefull booke
Those dreadfull flames she also found delayd,
She found: for now that fained dreadfull flame,
And of the dreadfull discord, which did driue
They which from shore behold the dreadfull sight
All mightie men and dreadfull derring dooers,
The hideous Chaos keepes, their dreadfull dwelling is.
With dreadfull force, and furious intent,
The dreadfull stroke in case it had arriued,
His dreadfull souse auoydes, it shunning light,
So dreadfull were his strokes, so deadly was his hond.
With that he driues at them with dreadfull might,
That euery one gan shun his dreadfull sight,
That dreadfull seem'd to euery liuing wight,
With dreadfull force falles on some steeple hie;
Ah dreadfull tidings which thou doest declare,
With dreadfull strokes let driue at him so sore,
Thence forth she past into his dreadfull den,
That would haue maz'd a man his dreadfull face to vew.
With dreadfull weapon aymed at his head;
So dreadfull strokes each did at other driue,
An hideous Giant, dreadfull to behold,
Against the storme of euery dreadfull stoure:
No warre was knowne, no dreadfull trompets sound,
His dreadfull heast, much lesse him match in fight,
And dreadfull battaile twixt them do darraine:
The trembling foule dismayd with dreadfull sight
So terribly his dreadfull strokes did thonder,
What strokes, what dreadfull stoure it stird this day:
From dreadfull mouth of death, which threatned sore
With dreadfull force he flies at her byliue,
He to her lept with deadly dreadfull looke,
And dare euen deathes most dreadfull face behold?
Towards her chamber; at which dreadfull stound
Like one adawed with some dreadfull spright.
Let driue at her with all her dreadfull might,
Which dreadfull sight, when all her warlike traine
Where is that dreadfull manly looke? where be
The dreadfull sight did them so sore affray,
The cruell Souldan, and with dreadfull fate
A dreadfull depth, how deepe no man can tell;
Full dreadfull wight he was, as euer went
Through the sad terror of so dreadfull fate,
Of horrible aspect, and dreadfull mood,
Vnto a dreadfull Monster to deuoure,
Whose dreadfull shape was neuer seene of none
A dreadfull feend, with fowle deformed looke,
Dealing his dreadfull blowes with large dispence,
With bils and glayues making a dreadfull luster;
With dreadfull looke he Artegall beheld,
With dreadfull terror, and with fell intent;
A dreadfull feend of gods and men ydrad,
The heauy burden of whose dreadfull might
Like as a ship with dreadfull storme long tost,
To her the Gods, for her so dreadfull face,
With dreadfull force they all did him assaile,
Who when he once his dreadfull strokes had tasted,
His lookes were dreadfull, and his fiery eies
The which descended with such dreadfull sway,
His dreadfull hand he heaued vp aloft,
And with his dreadfull instrument of yre,
Who being now in dreadfull darknesse layd,
With cruell rage and dreadfull violence
In dreadfull darknesse dreadfully aghast;
Gan all vpon him lay: there gan a dreadfull fight.
And had endured many a dreadfull stoure
Brought forth with him the dreadfull dog of hell,
And can let driue at him so dreadfullie,
So dreadfully he towards him did pas,
Ouer the sea, suspended dreadfully,
Full dreadfully he shooke that all did quake,
Dreadfully dropping from her dying hart,
So dreadfully he did the anduile beat,
And lashing dreadfully at euery part,
Full dreadfully empurpled all with bloud;
With yron wheeles and hookes arm'd dreadfully,
The whilest at him so dreadfully he driue,
Thereat he brayed loud, and yelled dreadfully.
So dreadfully his hundred tongues did bray,
Like troubled ghost did dreadfully appeare,
Let driue at him so dreadfully amaine,
In dreadfull darknesse dreadfully aghast;
Still dreading death, when she had marked long,
As no whit dreading any liuing wight;
The dreadlesse courage of this Elfin knight,
Dreadlesse (said he) that shall I soone declare:
Whom he assayld with dreadlesse hardiment,
Vnlesse it be perform'd with dreadlesse might.
Can dread of ought your dreadlesse hart withhold,
Yet cold through feare, and old conceiued dreads;
As one then in a dreame, whose dryer braine
A fit false dreame, that can delude the sleepers sent.
A diuerse dreame out of his prison darke,
And on his litle winges the dreame he bore
Now when that ydle dreame was to him brought,
And made him dreame of loues and lustfull play,
That troublous dreame gan freshly tosse his braine,
That feigning dreame, and that faire-forged Spright
Out of his swowning dreame he gan awake,
But lay as in a dreame of deepe delight,
As one out of a deadly dreame affright,
Suddeinly out of his delightfull dreame
In senselesse dreame; which sight at first him sore aghast.
Out of his dreame, that did him long entraunce,
He marueild more, and thought he yet did dreame
As one out of a dreame not waked well,
And hong adowne his head, as he did dreame:
As one that had out of a dreame bene reard,
And made him dreame those two disloyall were:
Like one that from his dreame is waked suddenlye.
They doe to thee in this same dreame discouer.
So blesse thee God, and giue thee ioyance of thy dreame
Like one that out of deadly dreame awooke:
And dreames, gan now to take more sound repast,
But whether dreames delude, or true it were,
Deuices, dreames, opinions vnsound,
Streight way with dreames, and with fantasticke sight
Is broken with some fearefull dreames affright,
Others like Dogs, others like Gryphons dreare,
From mortall vew, and wrap in darkenesse dreare;
Nathlesse it fell with so despiteous dreare
And powred forth his wretched life in deadly dreare.
Right in the flanke him strooke with deadly dreare,
Both to her loue; and to her selfe in that sad dreare.
And deare affection of so dolefull dreare,
With drearie shriekes did also her bewray;
Darke, dolefull, drearie, like a greedie graue,
A drearie corse, whose life away did pas,
The drearie image of sad death appeares:
With drearie drouping eyne lookt vp like one aghast.
Vp then, vp dreary Dame, of darknesse Queene,
Ye dreary instruments of dolefull sight,
